185940060.review: Fun but this game is so incredibly [b] hard [/b]. Some challenges rely more on luck than skill, and many will have you retrying so often that you might feel like throwing your controller in frustration. The difficulty balance feels off in many cases—some medium challenges should be hard, while some hard ones feel more like easy or medium. There also seems to be an overabundance of medium and hard challenges compared to easy ones. Sometimes, you just want to relax and tackle a quick, fun challenge, but outside of free-roaming, those moments are hard to come by.

185848703.review:
Игра с очень высоким потенциалом, которую испортил кривой геймдизайн и рандом. Я катаюсь на горных лыжах и в реальности это проще делать чем в этой игре. Кто придумал в игре позиционирующей себя как симулятор фрирайда, контрольные точки в виде маленьких круглешков куда надо заехать на скорости? А их бывает пара десятков и это не создает челленджа, это просто невероятно раздражает. У игры есть огромный потенциал (что обидно) и вроде как было бы достаточно указать начало и конец трассы и как ехать решай сам (на то оно и фрирайд), но они сделали контрольные точки какого-то минимального размера в местах куда иногда вообще не заехать.
Рандом это отдельная тема. Понять что будет с тобой во время поездки невозможно - когда ты приземлишься во время прыжка, когда не приземлишься, когда ты умираешь когда нет, просто какой-то набор случайностей.
В итоге, самое интересное, это просто выбрать самому точку и съезжать с нее на скорости, но в таком виде это увы просто технодемка, а не игра

185446529.review: Now everyone has the same question, is it worth the money for a skiing game. First of all, if we look at the gameplay, we have a very smooth and powerful game, the gameplay is really comfortable and the sound of the wind hitting you in the face while jumping off a ramp creates the effect of hitting you in the face. As for the story, first of all this game is a sports game, so don't expect too much from the story, but it's not like it doesn't exist. There are 8 sports in the game right now, but one of them is sledding, I don't know if it counts as a sport and it gives you the feeling of being extreme in all sports. There is a lot of music in the game, so the producers have chosen a very good list. For creators, you can turn off copyrighted music in the settings section, and I think it's a small detail, but it's a well-thought-out delicacy. If we talk about the atmosphere, it is a very cold environment, after all, the game is set in the Alps, the game has a really twisted map and there are drop zones on this map that you need to open by going to certain places. Obviously it's hard to open these places on foot. But the pleasure of the job is to walk around the map and find those places yourself. Anyway, if we come to the main subject, I think it deserves the desired price with its game structure and big map that does not make you faint. I recommend everyone who loves winter sports to take a look.

185086224.review:
[h1] Captivating at first sight, but gradually monotonous and homogeneous [/h1]

[h2] 8/10 [/h2]

[h3] Opening [/h3]

The Alps are one of nature's most amazing creations. Its snow-capped peaks, clad in white, fascinate countless tourists. Its highest peak, Mont Blanc, has long been a popular place for winter outdoor sports such as hiking, mountaineering, and skiing. Unfortunately, due to its geographical location, visitor flow rate, and danger, not everyone has the opportunity and courage to experience its wonders in person. Steep is a game centered on the Alps, and includes famous skiing locations such as Alaska, Japan, and South Korea. It allows players to enjoy the snow-capped mountain scenery and extreme snow sports without any risk. Whether you are engaging in various extreme sports and stunt performances, indulging in the pleasure of death and limits, releasing adrenaline madly; or strolling in this quiet and beautiful winter world, feeling the sunrise and sunset of the snow-capped mountains and the vast natural scenery of white snow, everything is up to the players to choose.

[h3] Strength [/h3]

The game uses an open world as its core gameplay. Players can explore many peaks around the Alps, and they can switch to locations such as Alaska, Japan, and South Korea. Steep focus on advancing through a wide variety of challenges, including performing dazzling stunts and winning applause by demonstrating exquisite operating skills; surpassing yourself in the checkpoint race for precision and speed; experiencing the thrill of brushing against death in a highly dangerous wingsuit flight; enjoying the beautiful natural scenery during a slow and romantic paragliding flight; flying at top speed in a rocket wingsuit flight that is extremely out of touch with reality and maximizes speed and excitement; letting yourself go in the fast and powerful downhill... In addition, players can also experience mountain stories and feel the charm of snow sports and its stories of the Alps according to preset routes.

Steep adopts a large-scale multiplayer online design, and the level is progressive from shallow to deep, easy to difficult. The game's dynamic and outstanding pop music selection, humane and easy-to-grasp operation, and simple yet intuitive interface all bring an excellent gaming experience. Compared to similar games, Steep is not really hardcore or realistic in terms of gameplay. The stunts in the game are not only easy to play, but the penalties for player mistakes are relatively low. Players can even pass levels by coasting after falling down, which is an extremely funny design.

[h3] Weakness [/h3]

Unlike racing games, which can constantly bring players new gaming and visual experiences through different car models and maps, the gameplay of Steep itself is relatively monotonous and homogeneous. The sports equipment available for selection in the game only differs in appearance, with no actual difference in performance. As players spend more time in the game and are immersed in this snowy world for a long time, the initial shock and delight will soon fade away, and aesthetic fatigue is inevitable. In addition to the unreasonable design of the medal standards for some of the game's medium and high difficulty levels, there is also a huge gap in the difficulty of different challenges in the game itself: the stunt performances are obviously easy, while the racing is a bit too difficult. The game itself has very few guiding elements, too. Apart from appearance, level, and challenge results, it also provides very limited positive feedback to players.

Mountain View, which is used to switch the game map of the challenge project, the logic, and perspective dragging are extremely weird, the actual experience is totally awful. Steep also has problems such as the inability to pause ongoing challenges, mandatory internet access to play game content, Ubisoft's terrible online servers, and all kinds of weird game bugs, all of which together greatly ruin the player's gaming experience. Road to the Olympics, a DLC that greatly expands the game's content and gameplay, cannot be purchased directly due to copyright issues and can only be activated again through CDkey.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]

Although the entry threshold of Steep is very low, it is essentially a game that selects players very much. Due to the highly monotonous and homogeneous gameplay, not everyone can tolerate this kind of environment, and there are only a few players who can truly experience and fully play most of the content in the game. 

Even so, Steep can still be regarded as one of the best skiing games on the market today. If you dream of strolling in a virtual Alps snow world and are interested in winter and snow outdoor extreme sports, Steep is definitely worth a try. This work can indeed bring you a good time, even if it may not last long, comes and goes quickly, and it's quite enough for a game originally released in 2016. Of course, if you can accept this kind of game mode and are willing to explore it, then you and Steep are a match made in heaven. The extremely rich challenges will surely bring you endless fun.

[b] At the end of the review, I would like to pay tribute to the following two people: the first is Matilda Rapapor, who was an outstanding freestyle skier, unfortunately, died in an accident while filming a promotional video for Steep in 2016; the second is supercat, a player from China, who experienced the beautiful scenery of the Alps and feeling of freedom through Steep while suffering from illness, but unfortunately passed away later. [/b]

Verily, *Steep* is a most wondrous diversion, worthy of high praise and admiration. Prithee, dost thou not long for the icy embrace of the mountain’s chill and the boundless freedom of the open skies? Lo, this game delivereth such marvels in abundance, as though the very heavens themselves had bestowed it upon us.

One shall glide upon the snow with skis or board, descend with grace or reckless abandon, and take to the skies with contraptions most daring. The vastness of the world is naught but awe-inspiring, a realm where one’s spirit of adventure shall be free to roam unbridled. Thou mustn't spurn the opportunity to partake in these most glorious exploits, for the experience doth invigorate the heart and quicken the soul.

Hark! The challenges, though many, are but a forge for thy skills, and with time and perseverance, thou shalt conquer even the most perilous peaks. Truly, *Steep* is no mere game, but a hymn to the grandeur of nature and the indomitable will of man. To shun it would be folly most grievous, for it is a treasure to be cherished by all who seek adventure.

One more run, right here, and then I’ll sleep...
This phrase quickly became my nightly ritual because time in Steep just flies by.

This game is all about insane descents and breathtaking flights. You find a crazy, risky route, make it down without crashing, feeling like a true daredevil, and then jump into a mission where you're asked to fly a wingsuit through gaps so narrow you wouldn’t even walk through them. And that's when you realize: the developers are way crazier than you are!

The visuals, physics, and overall experience — everything is top-notch.

Steep is a perfect blend of adrenaline, beauty, and freedom, and it’s something you’ll want to keep coming back to again and again.

183694122.review:
Day 1
The climb up the mountain was brutal today. The winds bit at my face, and each step felt like a negotiation with the icy cliffs. My gear held up—thank the gods for that—but the altitude is starting to wear on me. I found a good spot near the ridge to set up camp. The view? Unreal. Stars blanketed the sky, and below, the valley glimmered like it was alive.

As I prepped my skis for tomorrow's run, I could feel the anticipation building. The mountain demands respect, but it also calls to you. I stoked the fire, poured some coffee from my thermos, and huddled in my sleeping bag, dreaming of carving down fresh powder at dawn.

Day 2
The morning was calm—eerily calm. My gear was ready; I was ready. Just as I strapped on my helmet and tightened my boots, the serenity was shattered by a sound that could chill the bones of even the most hardened mountaineer.

A blood-curdling cry tore through the stillness, echoing off the peaks. I whipped my head around just in time to see him.

Captain Snowboard.

The man, the myth, the utter chaos. He emerged from the ridge above me, bombing downhill at a speed that defied logic, physics, and probably some local ordinances. Goggles reflecting the morning sun, a billowing red cape flapping behind him, boots barely hanging on, and—oh yeah—he was wearing shorts. Nothing else. Shorts.

I swear I saw him grin as he soared past, carving through ice and rock like a madman. The mountain wasn’t his enemy; it was his accomplice. My planned descent became a mere footnote to his epic flight of insanity.

Verdict
Steep is less a game and more an experience. You’ll battle nature, master the art of skiing, and maybe, just maybe, witness legends like Captain Snowboard in their purest, wildest form. The slopes aren’t for the faint of heart, but they’re waiting for you.

10/10. Will return to the mountain, but next time, I’m bringing a cape.
